newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Opp'n says small business hurting.
newsitem.headline: Australian Opp'n says small business hurting.

text.p: The fall in Australia's April retail sales on Friday confirmed that small businesses were being hard hit by low consumer confidence, opposition treasury spokesman Gareth Evans said.
"Small business is hurting," Evans said in a statement, adding that there had been no lift in consumer confidence or spending.
Retail sales fell 1.7 percent in April, seasonally adjusted, to A$10.29 billion, after falling 0.3 percent to A$10.46 billion in March, official data showed.
Evans also said the slight improvement in the current account deficit in the March quarter was not something the government could be proud of in a flat economy.
The current account deficit narrowed to A$4.587 billion in the March quarter from A$5.262 billion in the December quarter.
The government was also unlikely to meet its 3.25 percent growth forecast this year, or even growth of 3.0 percent, he said, pointing to its disastrous effect on jobs.
"Even the Prime Minister (John Howard) agrees we need a growth of four percent or better to significantly and rapidly reduce our unacceptably high unemployment rate."
